data.title: Columbia Sportswear issues mixed Q4 results, sets profit outlook below street view
data.description:
Shares of Columbia Sportswear Company (NASDAQ:COLM) are losing ground in Tuesday’s after-hours trading as a below-consensus Q4 profit coupled with lackluster guidance for 2025 drove shares down as much as 10%.

Sales were up 3% from a year ago to $1.096B and beat the consensus estimate of $1.08B while net income was 16% higher from a year ago to $1.80 per share but missed Wall Street’s expectations by $0.14.

“During the year we made substantial progress on our inventory reduction efforts, achieved cost savings through our Profit Improvement Program, and returned meaningful cash to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends. We also laid the foundation for Columbia’s ACCELERATE Growth Strategy, which will come to life in the seasons ahead,” CEO Tim Boyle said, adding that the company will continue to pursue cost savings to enhance profitability.

Looking ahead to 2025, Columbia’s (NASDAQ:COLM) guidance reflects its expectations as of Feb 4 and cautions that it is subject to “significant risks and business uncertainties,” namely U.S. trade policy that could adversely impact the company’s material sourcing and foreign sales. This puts anticipated earnings at $3.80 to $4.15 per share versus $3.82 in 2024 and below the consensus forecast of $4.35. This includes an anticipated 1% to 3% increase in sales.

Additionally, Columbia (NASDAQ:COLM) said it will pay a quarterly dividend of $0.30 per share on March 21 to shareholders of record as of March 10.

data.title: Brookfield Asset Management closes deal to broaden shareholder base
data.description:
Brookfield Asset Management (NYSE:BAM) and Brookfield Corp. (NYSE:BN) completed on Tuesday a previously announced arrangement that's intended to enhance BAM's corporate structure and broaden its shareholder ownership. The arrangement paves the way for the stock's inclusion in widely followed U.S. market indices, which should broaden its shareholder base and increase the liquidity of its shares.

BAM shares rose 5.1% in after-hours trading.

Through the transaction, Brookfield Asset Management (NYSE:BAM) acquired ~73% of the outstanding common shares of Brookfield's asset management business from BN in exchange for 1,194,021,145 newly issued class A limited voting shares of BAM, on a one-for-one basis. As a result, BAM has a total of 1,637,198,026 class A shares, of which BN retains an ~73% interest. Based on BAM's closing price of $58.19 on Feb. 3, 2025, the company's market capitalization stands at $95.3B.

data.title: Peter Thiel-back crypto exchange works with Jefferies on potential IPO - report
data.description:
Cryptocurrency exchange Bullish Global, whose backers include billionaire venture capitalist Peter Thiel, is weighing an initial public offering as soon as this year, according to a media report dated Tuesday.

In 2021, Bullish laid out plans to go public through a SPAC merger, but they were ultimately put on hold.

The company, led by CEO Tom Farley, is working with investment banking firm Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) on the potential debut, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg, adding that deliberations remained ongoing and the offering's details were subject to change.

Bullish boasts more than 275 staffers with offices in the U.S., Hong Kong, Singapore, Gibraltar and the Cayman Islands, its website showed.

data.title: Amgen sets 2025 revenue, EPS guidance ranges that include consensus
data.description:
• Amgen (NASDAQ:AMGN) released 2025 revenue and guidance ranges as part of its 2024 Q4 and full-year financial results after Tuesday's closing bell, and both include the consensus figures.
  • Revenues are projected to be $34.3B-$35.7B. Consensus is $34.53B. Non-GAAP EPS is estimated at $20.00-$21.20. Consensus is $20.82.
  • The biopharma's Q4 results beat on the top and bottom lines.
  • In the quarter, non-GAAP EPS increased 13% from $4.71 to $5.31
  • Amgen was helped in the quarter by an 11% year-over-year increase in product sales to ~$8.7B.
  • Prolia (denosumab) and Enbrel (etanercept) remained the company's two best-selling drugs, earning, respectively, ~$1.2B and ~$1B. Prolia sales rose 5% compared to Q4 2023 while Enbrel sales were flat.
  • Tavneos (avacopan) and Amjevita/Amgevita (adalimumab) saw the greatest increases, percentage-wise, in sales at 84% YoY. Amjevita/Amgevita is a biosimilar of AbbVie's (ABBV) Humira.

data.title: AMD reports record Q4 revenue, continues to gain market share
data.description:
Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) Q4 2024 financial results demonstrated record revenue growth for the quarter and showed the chipmaker increasing its market share, likely at the expense of rival Intel (NASDAQ:INTC).

For the quarter ended December 31, AMD reported adjusted earnings per share of $1.09 which was in line with the consensus estimate. Fourth quarter revenue was a record $7.7B, which was nearly $200M more than the estimate.

Looking ahead to the quarter in progress, AMD expects revenue ranging from $6.8B to $7.4B, with a midpoint of $7.1B more than the estimate of $7.04B.

"Data Center segment annual revenue nearly doubled as EPYC processor adoption accelerated, and we delivered more than $5B of AMD Instinct accelerator revenue," said AMD CEO Lisa Lu. "Looking into 2025, we see clear opportunities for continued growth based on the strength of our product portfolio and growing demand for high-performance and adaptive computing."

"Despite the market headwinds in devices, AMD gained market share with its AMD Ryzen processors as the segment grew 52% year-over-year in FY24," said Seeking Alpha analyst Michael Del Monte. "At the midpoint, Q1 2025 guidance is calling for a 7% year-over-year top-line decline, likely in part the result of Client inventory digestion following a strong quarter of sales growth."

However, AMD continues to trail its rival Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) in artificial intelligence accelerators.

"While Data Center revenue was up 69% year-over-year in Q4, the relatively small $3.9B revenue number split between Instinct and EPYC CPUs isn't doing bullish sentiment any favors," said Joe Albano, Investing Group Leader for Tech Cache. "AMD continues to show relatively weak sales versus Nvidia when it comes to AI accelerators."

The earnings results did demonstrate that AMD appears to be taking market share from its other chip rival Intel (NASDAQ:INTC).

"Client segment up 58% in the quarter is, however, a testament to AMD capitalizing on Intel's 13th and 14th-generation client CPU woes as I see anecdotal evidence of Intel enthusiasts (consumers) staving off Intel purchases and some even going to team red," Albano added. "If AMD can improve its high-margin Embedded segment in 2025, it could turn margins up further and provide for some clear sailing for revenue and bottom-line growth, giving the stock a shot at recovering much of its 2024 losses."

data.title: Super Bowl midweek preview: Sportsbooks want the Kansas Chiefs to win in a low-scoring game
data.description:
The American Gaming Association estimated that Americans will wager a record $1.39 billion legally on Super Bowl LIX. "This figure underscores the positive impact of the legal market—from protecting consumers to generating tax revenue that benefits communities across the country—while enhancing the game experience for all," highlighted AGA President Bill Miller.

For investors in the sports betting sector, how the game shakes out could have significant implications for Q1 earnings reports because the sportsbooks have embedded liability on certain results. As it stands on February 4, a low scoring game and Kansas City Chiefs victory could lead to a hold rate of about 22% due to a huge amount of betting on the points scored going over the 48.5-point line and with most sportsbooks having more exposure on the moneyline to a win by the Philadelphia Eagles.

Parlays and prop bets could also impact the Super Bowl hold rate if some of the long-odds bets hit.

Naturally, DraftKings (NASDAQ:DKNG) and FanDuel owner Flutter Entertainment (NYSE:FLUT) have the largest exposure to the Super Bowl results. Both companies will also be looking to add new customers over Super Bowl week and carve out even more market share. Notably, Genius Sports (GENI) could benefit from a highly competitive game that keeps in-game betting humming, according to Macquarie.

Stocks with ties to sports betting in general include MGM Resorts International (NYSE:MGM), Caesars Interactive (CZR), Rush Street Interactive (RSI), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Penn Entertainment (PENN), Bally's Interactive (BALY), Sportradar (SRAD), Genius Sports (GENI), GAN Limited (GAN), Churchill Downs (CHDN), Boyd Gaming (BYD), Elys BMG Group (OTC:ELYS), Gambling.com Group (GAMB), and SharpLink Gaming (SBET). Privately owned Fanatics and Hard Rock International are also active in sports betting in the U.S.

data.title: Snap in charts: Average revenue per user rises most in Europe in Q4

data.description:
• Douglas Emmett press release (NYSE:DEI): Q4 FFO of $0.38 beats by $0.01.

data.title: Snap surprises Wall Street with Q4 beat as advertisers double
data.description:
Snap’s (NYSE:SNAP) investment in artificial intelligence to bolster its ad business coupled with a 9% increase in daily users paid off in the final quarter of 2024 as the company reported a 14% increase in sales, beating Wall Street’s expectations by $10M and doubling profits from a year ago.

Shares were launched higher, trading with a double-digit gain in after-hours trading.

“In 2024 we made significant progress on our core priorities of growing our community and improving depth of engagement, driving top line revenue growth and diversifying our revenue sources, while building toward our long-term vision for augmented reality,” said CEO Evan Spiegel, noting that the number of active advertisers more than doubled in Q4 thanks to improvements to its advertising platform. In addition, the number of paid subscribers on its Snapchat+ platform doubled to 14M from a year ago contributing to a 131% year-over-year surge in "other revenue."

Looking ahead to the current quarter, Snap (NYSE:SNAP) expects revenue to be between $1.33B to $1.36B, exceeding estimates of $1.33B, while adjusted EBITDA is targeted for $40M to $75M, below $79.9M estimates. The company will provide further guidance during its earnings call.

data.title: Duke Energy, Tampa Electric customers face sharply higher bills for storm costs
data.description:
The Florida Public Service Commission approved sharp increases on Tuesday for customers of Duke Energy (NYSE:DUK) and Emera's (OTCPK:EMRAF) Tampa Electric of at least $20/month, as part of the two companies' attempts to recover costs from last year's hurricane season, the Tampa Bay Times reports.

The Tampa Electric (OTCPK:EMRAF) hike caused the most consternation from the PSC, as the company estimated that recouping its costs from hurricanes Debby, Helene, Milton, as well as Idalia in 2023 would result in customers spending more than $30/month than they already pay.

Tampa Electric (OTCPK:EMRAF) residential customers will pay ~$20/month additional for 1,000 kwh, a company representative said at the PSC hearing, which is slightly below the average amount households use.

Duke Energy (NYSE:DUK) customers using the same amount of electricity will see a surcharge of ~$32/month more due to the commission’s vote Tuesday, although an unrelated seasonal adjustment would offset ~$10, the company has said,even as the discount lasts only through November while the storm surcharge continues through February 2026.
